For applications like Jira and Confluence Cloud, users are able to request apps, which will populate the *App requests* tab from the administration and trigger an email to admins.

h3.Suggestion

Similar to [this Jira suggestion|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-74471] and the [on-prem edition|https://confluence.atlassian.com/upm/managing-user-requests-for-marketplace-apps-781394968.html#ManaginguserrequestsforMarketplaceapps-Disablinguserrequests], this is a suggestion to allow admins to disable users to request it due to reasons like the following ones:

# add edit restrictions to all pages (parent and children)
# make sure that the users with permission to edit the pages don't have "Restrictions" space permission
# try to move a child page inside the same page tree

The page moves

Currently, the only way to allow restricted pages to be moved is granting *Restrictions* space permission to the user that wants to move the page or ask someone with that permission to move the page.

fields.description:
For a user to be able to view a page on someone else's personal space, the user must have view rights to this personal space.

The word _*"sharing"*_ indicates that I make something available to others. Sharing a page with others should therefore make it possible for them to see this page, even if they do not have access to my space.
If additional security is required, a view request could be sent to the personal space owner for confirmation, for example, like it used to be on Confluence Server, when someone was trying to access for the first time and required an admin confirmation.
If this type of sharing is not possible then the whole concept of the personal space is rather useless, as it limits the space to pure personal usage - or requires rather complicated gymnastics with restrictions.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

It is possible to enable [public access|https://support.atlassian.com/confluence-cloud/docs/set-up-public-access/] on Confluence Cloud. With the recent implementation of CONFCLOUD-30161, unlicensed authenticated users can access content that is opened to Anonymous access. For example:
 * User has only access on Jira. 
 * Confluence is opened to Anonymous access.
 * User accesses Confluence while logged in. 

However, such scenario will only work in case the user belongs to the Instance userbase. Below scenario *won't work*:
 * User A has access on Jira from Instance A.
 * Instance B has Confluence opened to anonymous users.
 * User A (while authenticated to the Atlassian account) tries to access Instance B.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create an Instance (Instance A), and add a user to it (User A).
 # Create another Instance (Instance B), and add Confluence to it.
 # Enable anonymous access on Confluence.
 # While logged in as User A (that doesn't have licensed access on Instance B), access Confluence from Instance B.

h3. Expected Results

The user should be able to access the content, since it is publicly accessible.
h3. Actual Results

The user can't access the content. 
h3. Workaround

Accessing the Instance using the incognito mode or logging out of the Atlassian account would work.
fields.summary: Authenticated users can't access a Confluence Instance opened to anonymous access

fields.description:
h3.Summary

By default, Confluence has the [Collaborative Editing feature|https://support.atlassian.com/confluence-cloud/docs/create-edit-and-publish-a-page/#Create-edit-andpublish-Collaborativeediting] so multiple users can edit the same draft together and have all changes published.

This is a great feature to help with collaboration, avoiding losing changes published by someone and also, make it practical to publish it all at once. However, for users that would like to keep their changes in the draft state for further review, this provides a challenge if someone publishes the page.

Although Confluence has a warning stating that changes added by other users will be also added, people can still publish the changes without the consent of the other user that is adding content to the draft.

h3.Suggestion

This is a suggestion to allow the changes made by a specific user to be kept as a draft while other users will publish the page. For example, some alternatives:

* Allow users to only publish their own changes.
* During the warning, ask if People want to publish changes made by X, Y and, Z user(s) and select which one of them should be published.
* Restrict the publishing until all users editing the page confirm that the changes are ready from all sides.
* Allow users editing the page to select a "sharing" or "not sharing" mode. This way, if the user selects the "not sharing" mode, the changes will be only displayed for the account that selected it, avoiding other users publishing it.
fields.summary: Select or restrict changes to be published in Collaborative Editing

Add a valid Credit Card. In case of further issues after doing so, or in case you need to have the payment processed asap so you can install the desired app, create a support request using the below link and selecting: "Billing, payments, and pricing" and then "Problems with a payment or credit card"

Similarly raised in CONFSERVER-23771

When migrating from Confluence cloud to server/DC, some customers encounter warnings such as:
{code:java}
[Long running task: Importing data] [persistence.dao.hibernate.AbstractHibernateAttachmentDao$IntraHibernateAttachmentCopier] saveAttachmentData Attachment data size for 'Attachment: {{<file name> (file id) username}}' did not match attachment size. h3. Issue Summary

When using the [Page properties report macro|https://support.atlassian.com/confluence-cloud/docs/insert-the-page-properties-macro/] and sorting the columns using the "Sort By" function from the content of pages using the [Status macro|https://support.atlassian.com/confluence-cloud/docs/insert-the-status-macro/], the order will respect the colors of the status instead of the text due to this bug.

If the status is added with a specific color and then, it is changed, the order will remain as it is in the Page Properties Report macro.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create multiple pages.
 # On these pages, add the [Page properties macro|https://support.atlassian.com/confluence-cloud/docs/insert-the-page-properties-macro/] with a common column between them.
 # In these columns, add a text and then, [insert the Status macro|https://support.atlassian.com/confluence-cloud/docs/insert-the-status-macro/] and select a specific color for each.
 # Prior to publishing these pages, change the color of the status again.
 # Publish the pages and add a common label to them so they will be displayed in the report.
 # On a specific page, add the [Page properties report macro|https://support.atlassian.com/confluence-cloud/docs/insert-the-page-properties-macro/] and configure it to display the specific column and specific label.
 # Also on its configuration, add the column name for the one that has the Status macro on the *Sort By* field.

(i) This also happens when:
 * The color gets changed after editing the page again.
 * If someone copies the status macro from a different page, using a different color.

h3. Expected Results

The order should change so it would be based on the current color.
h3. Actual Results

The order does not change. Keeping it as it still had the previous color, although the color is changed on the report as well.
h3. Workaround
 * Tap the column name while viewing the page with the Page Property Reports macro so the sorting will be based on the text.
fields.summary: "Sort by" does not change if the color of status is modified in Page Properties Report

Error: [com.ctc.wstx.exc.WstxLazyException] Unexpected character ' ' (code 32) (missing name?) at [row,col{unknown-source}]: [1,483]{code}

We see the below error:
{code:java}
Error: [com.ctc.wstx.exc.WstxLazyException] Unexpected character ' ' (code 32) (missing name?) at [row,col{unknown-source}]: [1,483]{code}

h3. Summary

When [importing spaces|https://support.atlassian.com/confluence-cloud/docs/import-a-confluence-cloud-space/] that contain [Jira macros within them|https://support.atlassian.com/confluence-cloud/docs/insert-the-jira-issues-macro/], the *Jira macro repair* feature will put the names of the application links as "System Jira" as this is the default name of the Application Link for products that are under the same instance/URL, automatically connected.

If the user imports spaces from different Confluence instances that also have Jira, there will have multiple "System Jira" entries on the source part of the *Jira macro repair*, making it confusing to know which application link it should be routed to if Jira was not imported as well.

Even if the user integrates Confluence with the instance where the import is coming from, that has Jira as well, there will have no methods to know which "System Jira" is which.
h3. Suggestion

This is a suggestion to have the Jira macro repair using a different Application link name for the imported content instead of "System Jira".

For example, the name of the instance where the import came from, allowing multiple spaces to be imported from different instances without confusion.
fields.summary: Change the application link name of the source instance in Jira Macro Repair

h3. Issue Summary

As part of the [Jira integration with Confluence|https://support.atlassian.com/confluence-cloud/docs/use-jira-and-confluence-together/], users can use the [Application links|https://support.atlassian.com/jira-cloud-administration/docs/use-applinks-to-link-to-atlassian-products/] in order to connect both products and use macros like the [Jira Charts one|https://support.atlassian.com/confluence-cloud/docs/insert-the-jira-chart-macro/].

Although this macro can be used for externally connected (or if both products are automatically connected if they are under the same instance/URL) instances, if Confluence gets integrated with an external Jira and later, a [Jira product is added to the instance|https://support.atlassian.com/organization-administration/docs/add-a-new-product-to-your-organization/], users that have Confluence-only access will not be able to use the macro.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Have a Confluence-only instance (without Jira added to it).
 # Integrate Confluence with an external Jira instance via [Application links|https://support.atlassian.com/jira-cloud-administration/docs/use-applinks-to-link-to-atlassian-products/]
 # Once the authentication is finished, add a [Jira product to the instance|https://support.atlassian.com/organization-administration/docs/add-a-new-product-to-your-organization/]. This will make both Confluence and the new Jira to be automatically connected.
 # Have a user without access to the added Jira editing a page and [insert the Jira Charts macro|https://support.atlassian.com/confluence-cloud/docs/insert-the-jira-chart-macro/]

(i) Even if the external app links get removed, the macro will still not work if the user does not have access to Jira.
h3. Expected Results

The macro should be added to retrieve information from Jira.
h3. Actual Results

As soon as the macro is selected, it disappears, as if nothing happened. In the browser's console, the following error is displayed:
{code:java}
VM1001:1 Uncaught (in promise) SyntaxError: Unexpected token < in JSON at position 0
    at JSON.parse (<anonymous>)
    at Object.error (batch.js?build-number=6452&externals=__local-default__&locale=en-US:3783)
    at n (1.7.2.1-confluence-custom-m07.js:1)
    at Object.fireWith [as rejectWith] (1.7.2.1-confluence-custom-m07.js:1)
    at T (1.7.2.1-confluence-custom-m07.js:1)
    at r (1.7.2.1-confluence-custom-m07.js:1)

    at Object.makeRequest (batch.js?build-number=6452&externals=__local-default__&locale=en-US:3437) {code}
h3. Workaround

Grant the user with access to the newly added Jira instance through the *User management*
